citation.article-title: Ralstonia taiwanensis sp. nov., isolated from root nodules of Mimosa species and sputum of a cystic fibrosis patient.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Ralstonia taiwanensis sp. nov.
Ralstonia taiwanensis (tai.wan.en'sis. N.L. fem. adj. taiwanensis of Taiwan, where the root nodule strains were isolated)
Cells are Gram-negative, non-spore-forming and rod-shaped.
After 24 h growth on tryptic soy agar at 30 °C, the mean cell size is about 0.5-0.7 μm in width and 0.8-2.0 μm in length.
Tolerant to penicillin (10 μg per disc) and streptomycin (10 μg per disc).
No urease, β-galactosidase or DNase activity.
The DNA G+­C content is about 67 mol%.

Isolated from root nodules of Mimosa pudica and Mimosa diplotricha and from sputum of a cystic fibrosis patient and all strains have been deposited in BCCM/LMG Bacteria Collection (Laboratorium voor Microbiologie, Universiteit Gent, Gent, Belgium).
The type strain is LMG 19424T (=CCUG 44338T), which was isolated from the root nodule of Mimosa pudica.
Phenotypic characteristics of the type strain are the same as described for the species.
Its DNA G­+C content is 67.3 mol%.
